meta.description: Cross-category drug interaction scenarios for MedRep AI. Each scenario represents a common Indian comorbidity pattern where drug conflicts can be dangerous.

scenarios.title: Diabetic + Joint Pain
scenarios.patient_profile: Patient with diabetes taking Metformin, presenting with joint pain
scenarios.risk: NSAIDs reduce renal function → increased risk of Metformin accumulation → lactic acidosis
scenarios.mechanism: NSAIDs inhibit prostaglandin-mediated renal blood flow. Reduced GFR impairs Metformin clearance, leading to dangerous accumulation and lactic acidosis.
scenarios.recommendation: Use Paracetamol instead. It does not affect renal function and is safe with Metformin.
scenarios.demo_query: Can I prescribe Ibuprofen for a patient already on Metformin? What are the risks and cheaper alternatives?

scenarios.title: Cardiac + GI Issues
scenarios.patient_profile: Post-PCI/ACS patient on Clopidogrel with gastric complaints
scenarios.risk: Omeprazole inhibits CYP2C19, reducing Clopidogrel conversion to active metabolite → loss of antiplatelet efficacy → increased stent thrombosis/MI risk
scenarios.mechanism: Clopidogrel is a prodrug requiring CYP2C19 activation. Omeprazole is a potent CYP2C19 inhibitor, reducing active metabolite formation by up to 45%.
scenarios.recommendation: Use Pantoprazole instead. It has minimal CYP2C19 interaction and is safe with Clopidogrel (COGENT trial evidence).
scenarios.source: FDA safety communication; COGENT trial; AHA/ACC/ESC guidelines
scenarios.demo_query: My cardiac patient on Clopidogrel has acidity. Can I give Omeprazole?

scenarios.title: Hypertension + Pain
scenarios.patient_profile: Hypertensive patient on ARBs (Losartan/Telmisartan) needing pain relief
scenarios.risk: NSAIDs blunt antihypertensive effect of ARBs + combined renal risk (afferent + efferent arteriole constriction → acute kidney injury)
scenarios.mechanism: ARBs dilate efferent arteriole; NSAIDs constrict afferent arteriole. Together they reduce glomerular perfusion pressure, risking AKI. NSAIDs also cause sodium retention, counteracting BP lowering.
scenarios.recommendation: Use Paracetamol for pain. If NSAID is essential, use lowest dose for shortest duration and monitor renal function.
scenarios.demo_query: Can a hypertensive patient on Losartan take Diclofenac for back pain?

scenarios.title: Diabetic + Imaging
scenarios.patient_profile: Diabetic patient on Metformin scheduled for CT scan with IV contrast
scenarios.risk: IV contrast can cause transient renal impairment → Metformin accumulation → lactic acidosis
scenarios.mechanism: Iodinated contrast is nephrotoxic. The temporary GFR reduction impairs Metformin clearance. Standard protocol: withhold Metformin 48 hours before and after contrast.
scenarios.recommendation: Stop Metformin 48 hours before contrast administration. Restart only after confirming renal function (eGFR) is stable post-procedure.
scenarios.source: ACR Manual on Contrast Media; standard clinical practice
scenarios.demo_query: My diabetic patient needs a CT scan with contrast. What about their Metformin?

scenarios.title: Cardiac + Infection
scenarios.patient_profile: Patient on statin therapy (Atorvastatin) who develops an infection needing Azithromycin
scenarios.risk: Azithromycin prolongs QT interval (primary risk); atorvastatin has mild QT-prolonging potential. Combined use increases arrhythmia risk in susceptible patients.
scenarios.mechanism: Azithromycin blocks cardiac hERG potassium channels (QT prolongation — primary driver). Atorvastatin has mild QT effect. Risk of torsades de pointes increases in patients with baseline QT prolongation, electrolyte disturbance, or other QT-prolonging drugs. Unlike clarithromycin/erythromycin, azithromycin has minimal CYP3A4 effect, so statin myopathy risk is lower.
scenarios.recommendation: Short 3–5 day courses are usually safe. Monitor for QT prolongation; consider ECG if patient has other QT risk factors (elderly, electrolyte imbalance, other QT-prolonging drugs). Alternative: Amoxicillin if appropriate for the infection.
scenarios.source: OpenFDA label data; FDA drug safety communication on Azithromycin
scenarios.demo_query: Can I give Azithromycin to a patient already on Atorvastatin?

scenarios.title: Respiratory + Cardiac
scenarios.patient_profile: Patient with cardiac disease who also has asthma/COPD needing bronchodilator
scenarios.risk: Salbutamol (beta-2 agonist) causes tachycardia, palpitations, hypokalemia — problematic in patients with arrhythmias, CAD, or heart failure
scenarios.mechanism: Beta-2 agonists increase heart rate and myocardial oxygen demand. In CAD patients, this can trigger angina. Hypokalemia from high-dose salbutamol increases arrhythmia risk, especially with concurrent digoxin or diuretics.
scenarios.recommendation: Use lowest effective salbutamol dose. Monitor heart rate and potassium. For maintenance, prefer inhaled corticosteroids (Budesonide) as controller therapy to reduce rescue salbutamol use.

safer_alternative.name: Budesonide (as controller to reduce SABA use)

scenarios.demo_query: My cardiac patient with asthma is using Salbutamol frequently. Is this safe?

aspirin+ibuprofen.risk: Ibuprofen competitively blocks COX-1, reducing Aspirin's irreversible antiplatelet effect
aspirin+ibuprofen.recommendation: Avoid concurrent use in patients on low-dose aspirin for cardioprotection. Prefer paracetamol. If an NSAID is essential, consider the lowest effective dose of a short-course alternative (e.g., naproxen with PPI) and separate dosing from aspirin. Avoid long-term diclofenac in CVD patients (highest CV risk).
